stem: A 52-year-old client with a urinary tract infection (UTI) is increasingly confused and hypotensive. Based on the provided information, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, two appropriate nursing actions, and two essential parameters to monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: The patient is a 52-year-old female admitted with pyelonephritis secondary to a UTI, now showing signs of early septic shock.
Background: The patient has a history of type 2 diabetes, treated with oral medications. She initially presented with fever and flank pain three days ago. Urine cultures confirmed a gram-negative infection.
Assessment: At 14:00, the patient's blood pressure is 88/42 mmHg, heart rate is 122 bpm, respiratory rate is 26 breaths/min, and temperature is 39.6°C (103.2°F). The patient is confused and disoriented. Skin is warm, flushed, and dry. Urine output has decreased to 18 mL in the last 2 hours. Lactate level is 4.8 mmol/L.
Recommendation: Initiate sepsis protocol. Obtain blood cultures immediately. Administer a 30 mL/kg crystalloid bolus. Monitor MAP and lactate levels closely.

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: BP 88/42 mmHg, HR 122 bpm, RR 26 breaths/min, T 103.2°F (39.6°C), SpO2 94% on room air.

tabs.title: Lab Results
tabs.content: Lactate: 4.8 mmol/L; WBC: 18,000/µL; Creatinine: 1.8 mg/dL; BUN: 28 mg/dL

tabs.title: Radiology
tabs.content: CT scan of abdomen and pelvis shows evidence of pyelonephritis with no signs of abscess formation.

tabs.title: Medication Administration Record
tabs.content: Ceftriaxone 1g IV q24h (scheduled, not yet administered); Acetaminophen 650mg PO q4h PRN fever (last dose 08:00)

actionOptions.text: Obtain blood cultures (aerobic and anaerobic) from two sites
Administer a rapid IV bolus of 30 mL/kg crystalloid solution
Administer vasopressors if hypotension persists after fluid resuscitation
Apply cooling measures to address the elevated temperature

parameterOptions.text: Serum Lactate and Central Venous Oxygen Saturation (ScvO2)

rationale.correct: The client is exhibiting signs of early (warm) septic shock (c1), characterized by warm, flushed skin, fever, hypotension, tachycardia, and altered mental status. The elevated lactate level (4.8 mmol/L) confirms inadequate tissue perfusion despite increased cardiac output (hyperdynamic state). Priority nursing actions include obtaining blood cultures before administering antibiotics (a1) to identify the causative organism and initiating aggressive fluid resuscitation with a 30 mL/kg crystalloid bolus (a2) to address vasodilation and improve tissue perfusion. Monitoring Mean Arterial Pressure (MAP) (p1) and serum lactate levels (p2) are crucial for assessing the effectiveness of interventions and guiding further treatment. MAP reflects tissue perfusion pressure, and lactate clearance indicates improved oxygen delivery.
clinicalPearls: Early septic shock presents with warm, flushed skin due to vasodilation, while late septic shock presents with cold, clammy skin due to vasoconstriction.
A lactate level greater than 2 mmol/L is indicative of sepsis, and levels greater than 4 mmol/L suggest septic shock.
The Surviving Sepsis Campaign recommends a 30 mL/kg crystalloid bolus as initial fluid resuscitation for septic shock.

questionTrap.trap: Applying cooling measures to address the elevated temperature.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: While fever is present, the flushing in early septic shock is primarily due to vasodilation. Addressing the underlying hypotension and infection is the priority. Cooling measures alone will not resolve the shock state.

mnemonic.title: SEPTIC
mnemonic.expansion: S: Source identification (blood cultures), E: Early antibiotics, P: Pressors (if fluids fail), T: Target MAP (≥65 mmHg), I: IV fluids (30 mL/kg crystalloid bolus), C: Continuous monitoring (vitals, lactate)
